data.title: Warren Beatty or Robert Redford?
data.meta_description: By popular demand! A.K.A. @mattsby  Who do you prefer as an actor/director/piece of meat?
data.text:
Post by pacinoyes on

As an actor I think Beatty's leagues better and I'm of Pauline Kael theory on Redford that he never dug deep while making movies in an era where everyone was going deep in their acting. Beatty would often be rather daring in what he could got across - the possible homosexuality of Clyde is a scene literally I don't think Redford could play or would think to play like that. Beatty to me is the most underrated leading man ever in Hollywood.....

As a director they are closer I think and I admire Redford's restraint in some of his films - the way he can convey, as a filmmaker things that maybe he was fearful to try as an actor. The emotional coldness of Ordinary People and the emotional warmth of A River Runs Through It are impressive......but ultimately Beatty could write too and as a writer/director combined he edges Redford out there.

Post by Mattsby on

If a frog had wings he wouldn't bump his ass so much.

Beatty never needed to bump. In fact, idk if any major male star ever so cleverly used and subverted their public image on the screen. McCabe, Shampoo, and Bugsy, are like a trilogy of the myth of masculinity. And that's across genres. And there's Bonnie and Clyde where his lure itself is cornered and questioned. Those are four great performances, immensely charming and touched with unexpected sensitivity and humor. He's pushed himself - like Reds a palpable perf where he's driven and drained at the same time. Ishtar, alternatively, he's a childlike goof, lovable, hilarious, unafraid to look foolish. I've been impressed and surprised by all his perfs I've seen (still missing a few) except The Fortune, where he seems off.

Redford, who's been in I think more than double the amount of movies, has never impressed me. He can be good, and has been a bunch, but mostly to me is an average, predictable actor. He bumps- and I'm talking frogs, folks.

As for directing, that's a closer one - but still Beatty. There's his towering Reds, the evenly poignant Heaven Can Wait, the grotesquely fun Dick Tracy, Bulworth a flawed but very interesting piece of political satire, and there's Rules Don't Apply which is half mush and half a revealing reflection of Beatty's own meek mystique.

Lookswise, I didn't know debates could be this easy:

*Ahem* Did you know that she tried to seduce him and he rebuffed her advances? I wonder now if Meryl turned down a similar proposition...

I did hear that - I'm dying to see that Kael documentary "What She Said" and maybe they'll cover it there too ......there's an Arthouse theater sort of near me that has had a poster for it forever but with no date. Grrrrrrrr.

Post by Tommen_Saperstein on

Quintessential movie stars both but I've never been that impressed by Beatty outside of Reds and McCabe. Neither of these men are known for their range but Redford is sexier, more charismatic, and has the better slate of work IMO. I'll take The Sting, Three Days on the Condor and All Is Lost over any Beatty performance--McCabe perhaps being the only exception. I also appreciate that Redford turned in some of his greatest and most affecting work at the end of his career. The man aged like fine wine. Can't say the same for Beatty.

Post by countjohn on

As with other people in this thread I'd say Beatty is clearly the better dramatic actor. He's been quite good a number of times. To me Redford is a great star, but just okay in terms of pure acting chops.

I guess Redford for directing but it's not an entirely fair comparison since Beatty only directed like three movies. He also wielded a lot of control as a producer on a lot of his movies, like obviously Bonnie and Clyde, so you could almost say they were "his" even if he wasn't the director.

Post by Javi on

Beatty easily.

Redford I suppose I just don't "get" as an actor. Take his recent acclaimed turn in All Is Lost for example. Absolutely nothing was going on there imo and he is the movie so there's no excuse. Not a single idiosyncrasy in sight, hardly a suggestion of an inner life, no texture... just a (dubiously) old guy withering away on a boat, yacht, whatever it was

Newman vs. Beatty, now that'd be more even I think.

^

This ........so very much this......

Post by mattfincher on

Redford has an ineffable quality that sort of makes it hard to explain what makes/made him effective. It's also why some think he's great and some don't. I wouldn't call him a "deep" actor and he certainly didn't challenge himself the way I wish he would have. But what he was extremely good at is simply being/existing on screen in a way that only true movie stars can be/do. No histrionics, no "big" moments, simply a character existing within a space with a presence that commands attention without begging for it.

Maybe - Newman is pretty beloved on this board and he won the old GOAT poll on IMDB (too high imo but he's a top 10 American film actor for me) - finished 10th this time (that's closer) - in some ways he was the Nicole Kidman of his day - just a poll monster - people love him.

In general though Redford/Beatty is a great match-up in the looks, politics, played athletes, director thing........Newman/Lemmon is the closest equivalent to me since they really do fight it out for actor of the 60s (with George C. Scott who is a lesser star) - we had that poll fairly recently too.
